This is a bit verbose and not really needed (the loader interface should mostly never be needed by people. People also really shouldn't need get_session_client. I'd recommend instead:

  conn = openstack.connect(cloud='mordred')
  for server in openstack.compute.v2.server.Server.list(session=conn.compute):
    print(server.to_dict())

Also - good reminder that we should REALLY change the API of all of the resource objects (hahahahaha) so that this is list(adapter=conn.compute) ... because it actually takes an adapter not a session. But we don't have to do that in this patch.

> Also - good reminder that we should REALLY change the API of all of the resource objects (hahahahaha) so that this is list(adapter=conn.compute) ... because it actually takes an adapter not a session. But we don't have to do that in this patch.

Good point. Also, it says it can accept a generic keystoneauth Adapter object:

  >>> import openstack.resource
  >>> help(openstack.resource.Resource.list)
  Help on method list in module openstack.resource:

  list(session, paginated=True, base_path=None, allow_unknown_params=False, **params) method of builtins.type instance
      This method is a generator which yields resource objects.

      This resource object list generator handles pagination and takes query
      params for response filtering

      :param session: The session to use for making this request.
      :type session: :class:`~keystoneauth1.adapter.Adapter`
      ...

That's not true anymore, it seems:

  >>> from keystoneauth1.identity import v3
  >>> import keystoneauth1.session
  >>> import keystoneauth1.adapter
  >>> from keystoneclient.v3 import client
  >>> auth = v3.Password(
  ...     auth_url='http://172.20.4.155/identity',
  ...     username='admin',
  ...     password='password',
  ...     project_name='demo',
  ...     user_domain_id='default',
  ...     project_domain_id='default')
  >>> session = keystoneauth1.session.Session(auth=auth)
  >>> adapter = keystoneauth1.adapter.Adapter(
  ...     session=session,
  ...     service_type='block-storage',
  ...     interface='public',
  ...     version=3)
  >>> from openstack.block_storage.v3 import availability_zone
  >>> list(availability_zone.AvailabilityZone.list(session=adapter))
  Traceback (most recent call last):
    File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
    File "/home/ubuntu/openstacksdk/openstack/resource.py", line 1782, in list
      connection=session._get_connection(),
  AttributeError: 'Adapter' object has no attribute '_get_connection'

deploy-guide/source/post_deployment/dele.message: I think it's better to adjust number of characters(<80 chars) to be consistent with the other sections.
How about explaining that we rely on deployment plan in the subsequent overcloud node delete command thus we update here deployment plan to ensure everything is up to date?
Maybe --stack-only would be better here since --update-plan-only seems to be something we're deprecating. AFAIK --stack-only would achieve the same objective.
update-plan-only has been removed in master. So yeah we should get rid of this additional step.
If we are removing tail end of nodes, decreasing the scale count and running deploy command would be more appropriate, In that case we should refer to `:ref:scale_roles`. Can we include this here?
Not sure we want to be suggesting two different methods here? What do you see as the benefit of decreasing the Count and re-running the deployment, vs the node delete method suggested here?

Deleting nodes would blacklist the index right, if you are deleting tail end nodes, it'd be better to use scale-in operation than deleting nodes. same thing was mentioned in scale-role.rst
If some one directly looking into this document and not aware of scale-role itself, then this would redirect user to look into the other scale-role option as well to choose from.

There is an inherent issue with node delete where the node counts in templates and stack go out of sync. If after running a node delete, users don't reduce the node count in templates/environments in the next deploy, they would have issues with not enough hosts available.

We normally don't suggest node delete unless users want to blacklist nodes (hardware issues etc). For normal scale-down just reducing the count and deploying again is the right thing to do. For nodes that has temporary issues, DeploymentServerBlacklist can be used, which ignores those nodes for that deploy. It's probably better do document that somewhere, may be in the beginning of this section.
remove space at the end of the line.

ironic/drivers/modules/drac/utils.py.message:
Some ping implementations need timeout to be defined or they can hang. I consider this kind of risky and there is no guarantee that network firewalls may allow ICMP Echo-Request to the BMC. It is likely best to just try the TCP socket to the BMC and costs us less in terms of executing an external program versus a native python call on a tcp socket.

For what it is worth, I think about 30% of the deployments we see elevated security measures and filtering of traffic between controllers and the BMC. Most likely, they will find ironic requiring ping to be unacceptable from a risk management perspective should the infrastructure have an active attacker as pings can aid in recon to pivot an attack.

?
Let's avoid having two ways to express the same thing
Thanks for your insights!

This is a very good question. I'd be inclined to say we shouldn't support such syntax (and document this clearly) - it seems to me it can lead to confusion. What are your thoughts? Another thing is whether it would work (I'd have to refresh my understanding of MultiOpt and test this in the lab to comment on this with full confidence)

Some of the clean steps have a config defined to set the priority [1]. Which priority will take effect if the that config (Ex: [deploy]/erase_devices_metadata_priority) is defined along with 'deploy.erase_devices_metadata:123' ?

[1] https://github.com/openstack/ironic/blob/4a3bbf6d28eeede0bab36cf7ed412192c2300a1f/ironic/conf/deploy.py#L43-L57

Good question, I'm setting up a lab to validate another recently merged change and will test this out of curiosity too. Having said that I think it would be better if there is only one, clear way of setting priorities. I propose we deprecate [deploy]/erase_devices_metadata_priority and [deploy]/erase_devices_priority in a follow-up change.
I tested this in the lab, the priority set with clean_step_priority_override will take precedence as expected.

Different hardware types may have same clean step name (Ex: update_firmware is present in 'ilo' and 'redfish' hardware type [1]). The given config would apply the same given priority to clean steps of both the hardware types. 
For certain hardware it may be necessary to execute the various clean steps in a particular order to make it work. Such ordering for one hardware type may conflict with the ordering required for another hardware type. This config naming takes away the flexibility of having different priority values for same clean step defined across hardware types.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/ironic/blob/4a3bbf6d28eeede0bab36cf7ed412192c2300a1f/ironic/drivers/modules/ilo/management.py#L435-L440
[2] https://github.com/openstack/ironic/blob/4a3bbf6d28eeede0bab36cf7ed412192c2300a1f/ironic/drivers/modules/redfish/management.py#L709-L717
Note that update_firmware requires arguments and thus cannot be used in automated cleaning.
I propose we leave this out of the scope of this particular change, as the original story / RFE did not mention differentiating hardware types and I think this needs further discussion.

Update_firmware is a bad example, but the point I wanted to convey was different hardware types can have a clean step operations needing different ordering and that could be achieved by tweaking priority.
Can 'driver' name be added to key part of the config like ilo.management.clean_priority_reset_ilo:345? Or will it lead to too many configs for the same method supported across hardware types?

The problem is, what we do now does not scale. We cannot keep adding specific options for clean steps, especially with different interfaces.

Can you provide a real world example when someone would want different priorities for the same step in iLO and Redfish?

docker/octavia/octavia-base/extend_start.message: Unsure why we need to do it in both config.json and extend_start.sh?

For consistency. Workflow is as follows:
1. First start of octavia_api:
 - set_configs doesn't set permissions for /var/log/kolla/octavia because it doesn't exist.
 - extend_start creates /var/log/kolla/octavia and sets permissions for octavia:kolla
2. Restart of octavia_api:
 - set_configs sets octavia:octavia permissions recursively for /var/log/kolla/octavia
 - extend_start sets octavia:kolla permissions
And so on, and so on.

We could probably just set to octavia:octavia - but I found that in most of the places we do $USER:kolla probably for fluentd logs access?
I can see why it needs to be consistent if it's in both places, but why does it need to be in both places? I guess it doesn't matter too much.

deployment/frr/frr-container-ansible.yam.message: step_1 tasks are invoked in host_prep_tasks. It creates a difference in steps with FRR and without FRR. Is it possible to extract those required steps to host_prep_tasks in the respective services and invoke it as like Podman?

> My concern is that the well defined steps (in this case 'step1') is being executed in host_prep_tasks. That too only with FRR. It defeats the steps definition. I was trying to see if there is any alternative to avoid it.

You are not wrong :) I don't necessarily love the idea, but we could not come up with anything cleaner that did not involve ripping massive amounts of stuff out or changing how do thinks substantially.

Thanks Saravanan

So these common_deploy_steps_tasks_step_1.yaml are not run during host_prep_tasks normally, but in the deploy step tasks at step1 (common/deploy-steps.j2 'Overcloud common bootstrap tasks for step 1').

The difference is that with FRR enabled those tasks are executed twice (during host_prep_tasks due to this frr service and later during the "normal" run of 'Overcloud common bootstrap tasks for step 1'). They are idempotent so this should be okay (albeit obviously less than ideal)

I just don't know if 'Overcloud common bootstrap tasks for step 1' could be moved to host_prep_tasks in general or if it would break anything?

Not sure in which respective service we would move the tasks inside common_deploy_steps_tasks_step_1.yaml, or am I misunderstanding?

> Not sure in which respective service we would move the tasks inside common_deploy_steps_tasks_step_1.yaml, or am I misunderstanding?

Ok, misunderstood "deploy_step_tasks" on each service with "common/deploy-steps.j2". Its clear now. 

> They are idempotent so this should be okay (albeit obviously less than ideal)

My concern is that the well defined steps (in this case 'step1') is being executed in host_prep_tasks. That too only with FRR. It defeats the steps definition. I was trying to see if there is any alternative to avoid it.
or maybe we could just add step 0?.. later

I was just now leaving a comment in the commit message asking if we had explored moving FRR to step 0 when I read your message -- great minds think alike?! Heh.
Moving to step 0 would still require including tasks from common_deploy_steps_tasks_step_1.yaml but at least the podman bits could be dropped. Michele, what do you think? Have we tested/ruled out this option?

So the only way we can do this 100% cleanly is the following:
A) Split out the common_deploy_steps_tasks_step_1.yaml tasks from the deploy step loop and place them after host_prep_tasks and before the external deploy tasks
B) Create a new set of tasks that go after (A) and before external deploy tasks (call them pre-external-deploy or something) and move the frr setup tasks to (B)

So A) is https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/781963. We can also investigate doing B). My problem with all this is that we're adding plays which set ansible concurrency boundaries (i.e. tripleo_free does not cross separate plays), so we're adding slowness/complexity only for the frr case.
Oh, you're totally right. Sorry for the noise.

The problem is that step0 runs before the network and even before host_prep_tasks, so we could not pull down the containers and podman would run afterwards:
https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/common/deploy-steps.j2#L506
this is awful. it's really not great to duplicate all these. have we considered not bothering to containerize frr instead of doing this?

os_ken/lib/bfdlib.py.message:
I think this is not the correct approach.

We need:
1) To provide this functionality in BFDSession.
We need to be able to stop the "_send_loop" spawned thread, but this should be implemented in BFDSession class. For example, when the object is deleted or calling another method.

2) BFDLib should implement a method to delete the session. Here in BFDLib we create a BDF session instantiating a BFDSession object. We should be able to delete this object from "self.session" (as you do) and when the object is deleted, the thread should be finished.
Agree. A method like "kill" in BFDSession sounds reasonable. Perhaps the "kill" method in BFDSession call hub.kill(self.thread) and   self.session[discr].kill() can be called here.

After killing a thread, add a wait() method to ensure it ends.

hub.kill(self.session[discr].thread)
hub.joinall([self.session[discr].thread])
joinall() accepts "threads" (a list of threads), so I think it should be [self.thread].

This change made me realize that we need to re-init a few other things here too as well, like our global cell cache and service version cache. And when we add those we should add some verification to the same unit test.

> When we start the nova-api  on wsgi mode we always need the db

 > too, so I suppose they/we already fixed that point here.

Right. I took a look at the placement code and find this is how they have handled the scenario of reloading the wsgi application without restarting the process, with a @run_once decorator [1].

 > If not then we just have to pass `False` from the `wsgi_app` module
 > ot move away from this scenario.

We do need the database to do anything in nova, so we do want to pass True for a true application start. You are right that we could do something similar to placement (like @run_once), but that is assuming no other "gotchas" around global nova state that should be reset. If we miss some cases, we will still suffer problems, likely ones that are more hidden and harder to debug. Just a word of warning on this approach. We have a lot of similarity with placement but unfortunately we have more complexity too and more global state.

 > I've no ideas about the restart of the containers, IIRC it was
 > during an update so I suppose the restart come from some tripleo
 > things.

Yes, completely agree that the restart of containers would be a tripleo thing. My concern is that we might go on a hunt to reset all global states in nova and still miss some and still end up with problems (potentially hidden ones) in this reload-but-not-restart scenario and that it might be best to investigate the issue on the tripleo side as well, because the changes we try in nova will not be guaranteed to give us the fresh slate we need to work properly after a reload-but-not-restart. When overcloud nodes are rebooted, I really thought they should involve restarting the containers.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/placement/blob/2009e61335a43645e5d191546dbdc94709b221cd/placement/db_api.py#L32

we thought that db issue was hidden by the config issue. Previously we failed due to args that are registered twice because arguments were already parsed before. Now we goes away from the already parsed args and this error looks like to a race condition.

It looks a bit to:
- https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1643147 
- https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1636399

When we start the nova-api  on wsgi mode we always need the db first because the nova config module  will always try to connect to it [2]. This is due to the fact that  `configure_db` is set to True as the default value and we use this default value under the wsgi mode [3].

Previously (around OSP13 IIRC) a script was introduced to wait for the db before starting nova-api [2], this one was related to migration/sync and maybe we should take care to this scenario too, I mean waiting for the db first and then start nova in wsgi mode, (I've no ideas about the nova workflow and its needs). The rationale behind this script [2][5] really look like similar to our current issue - the db issue - unfortunatelly this script is only for nova-placement and also I noticed that another script [6] is used to wait for compute but it doesn t take care about db service.

Apologies for the delayed response -- I got pulled into several downstream issues the past week.

I spent some time today trying out this change in a unit testing environment and what I've found so far is that this change will not really solve the problem of the nova-api wsgi application being reloaded but not restarted.

I found that without the CONF.reset(), we hit the error as described in the bug:

 oslo_config.cfg.ArgsAlreadyParsedError: arguments already parsed: cannot register CLI option

However, with the CONF.reset(), we hit a new error:

 oslo_db.sqlalchemy.enginefacade.AlreadyStartedError: this TransactionFactory is already started

which is a problem of trying to re-initialize global oslo.db state without restarting the process.

So, I wanted to pause and ask at this point, has this change been tested anywhere and verified to work to enable the wsgi app to be reloaded? Because from what I have tried so far, it will not solve the problem and the problem then moves to a new place in the code.

We have a substantial amount of global state in nova that may not work properly to be re-initialized without restarting the nova process, so I'm beginning to think that this may not be a reasonable approach for solving the original issue you encountered.

I think there are some unanswered questions around the behavior of the nova_api containers in this scenario. When a node is rebooted, how/why are the containers not restarted? Is this intentional or is there a bug related to the containers not being restarted? I think we should explore this a bit to fully understand what is happening and where the fix needs to be made.

Thinking about it more, I think the cell cache and service version re-init should be part of this patch because it's part of the same issue of the wsgi app being reloaded and properly re-initialized. I will add that part and add a unit test for the re-inits.
Thanks Melanie for your feedback, lets me know if I can help you by doing some reviews or submitting some patches or related changes.
I know this works and is based on placement stuff, but a simple global variable would have done the same thing too
Sorry y'all, I thought copying the placement method would have been most liked by reviewers :(

Naked or not a global is a global, that causes trouble in testing. See https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1921098 

I prefer explicit over implicit. This is now an implicit global which makes it hard to notice that we are manipulating global state here.

Okay, so SchedulerEventQueue is the only subclass of this that doesn't implement __iter__, and it's also meant to be abstract.  This makes sense to me.

We could rename this to __iter__ and then do the following in the derived classes:

    for data, ack_ref in super().__iter__():
        ...

However, I would prefer not to do that as then the ZooKeeperEventQueue is not an ABC anymore.

Iterable is the abstract base class that has __iter__() as abstract method. We could add __iter__ again as @abstractmethod here to make it clear that ZooKeeperEventQueue is an ABC. 
The _iterEvents() method implements common logic that is then used by the concrete implementations. The __iter__ method is implementation dependent and can't be implemented. here.
For reference this uses ZooKeeperEventQueue as base class and has __iter__ which makes it a proper iterator.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
We should never leak a semaphore; it's a bug if we do.  And hopefully we've found all of those.  :)

But if we do, right now an operator can recover from that by restarting; but they won't have the option in the future.

Since this naming system makes it easy to determine if a semaphore lock is still valid, let's add this to the periodic cleanup we were talking about earlier:

Periodically check that every semaphore holder still exists, and if not, delete it and log an error message.

zuul/zk/event_queues.py.message: I agree with all of that.

We have to move this outside of the try/finally because otherwise we would delete the result path if we call wait with a short timeout.

In fact, this might be a bug in the current code if you call this method with a timeout, and the node is created between these two lines.  Ie:

1) [A] self._wait_event.wait(timeout) returns False
2) [B] node is created in other thread/process
3) [A] "return False" is executed
4) [A] finally clause is executed
5) [A] node created by B is deleted

I think my assumption was that if we hit a timeout the caller is not interested in the result anymore. This seems to be the way in which it is currently used.

With your implementation it's behaves more like a non-blocking wait (which is totally fine).
I think it makes sense this way as it is more consistent with the way futures work in Python (e.g. AFAIK it's safe to call concurrent.futures.Future wait() again after hitting a timeout)

Thinking about this some more it might make sense to extend the API to also allow "canceling" the future (basically just delete the result node). Currently if we hit a timeout we would leak the result nodes for the duration of the client lifetime. Not sure though if this is really an edge-case worth considering.

The timeout parameter is currently not used, but at some point we will get rid off the Gearman RPC mechanism and directly drop the events into the management event queue and wait for the future on the client side, e.g. zuul-web. In that case a timeout will probably be useful.

The tests are timing out because they're catching a race here; tests.unit.test_scheduler.TestScheduler.test_client_promote_negative processes the promote event that we put before we create the result node.  We need to do this in the other order; the only risk is that we will create a result node and then fail to create the actual event node.  In that case, we will leak the result node until this client restarts.  That's probably acceptable.

(We could try to delete the result node if we fail to create the event node, but the only reason we're likely to fail to create the event node is that ZK has gone away, so we're unlikely to be able to clean up immediately, and I think we want to go ahead and return the exception ASAP.)

zuul/driver/github/githubconnection.py.message:
This is a slightly confusing name, in that it's used above as the imperative name of a function "hey, computer, go process this event" and here it's used as a descriptive noun "an event related to processing".  Maybe we should call this something else ("_processing_event"?), or maybe we should rename the other function _processEvent().

I wouldn't mention it except I'm literally trying to figure out what this does right now and am searching through the file and have to guess which one I'm looking at.
Yes, that's indeed confusing. I'll rename the event to _notify_new_event or something along those lines.

How do we avoid processing the same events again on the next pass through this loop?

I think we'd need to maintain a set of event ids in the forward queue and skip those?
Good catch! I'll fix this in the next PS.

This has a race condition between the dispatcher and forwarder thread. An in-progress event might be acked and removed from the set between start of the iteration and the check here. This can lead to events being processed twice. In order to fix that we need to create a copy of the set before iterating.
